The Church's stance on these topics can be a major reason for people to leave. I don't see why priests can't be married or have female priests. Everyone else in the world has a job and a family life, so why can't priests?

transformed_texts: I think that the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. Their views on various issues seem outdated. Many people think the Catholic Church is losing influence because it's not very open to many things. They have strong views on topics like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which can be a turn-off for some people. If they were to adapt to a newer way of thinking, they might not lose their following. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because of how it views certain issues. The Catholic Church is against abortion, which can make it difficult for people who are pro-choice to be part of the community. The same goes for gay marriage and other similar issues. The Church's stance on these topics can be a major reason for people to leave. I don't see why priests can't be married or have female priests. The Church says that priests are "married" to God, but I don't think that's a valid reason for not allowing them to have a family life. Everyone else in the world has a job and a family life, so why can't priests?

I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't really put much thought into the topic, but I think it's wrong to say that it's not okay.

It doesn't seem like they have a choice in how they are. I mean, I was born straight, and another person might be born gay. It doesn't seem like they make a conscious decision that they should be held responsible for.

I think it's wrong for the federal government to get involved, as it's not a legal issue or a moral issue. I don't think these gay people should be put on a stage like they made a wrong decision or choice.

It doesn't seem like they have any right to interfere in people's lives, and they're just who they are. Gay people are who they were born to be, and they shouldn't be punished for that.

I think that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. And it's not just for women. I think it has to do with the specific field of work that one is in. I mean, in general, I feel that women have it harder because there's the "glass ceiling" where, even though it's supposed to be about equality, most people have a hard time finding someone to work under a woman if they're a man because the society has been raised for so long. And often, women in the workplace see that there's a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't promote them to that position because, historically, it's been shown that women are not usually in the upper levels of the business world. And I think the same thing goes for men. And in other fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's really rare for a man to be at home. And often, people look down on that because society thinks, "Oh, you're a man, you should be working. You should be the breadwinner of your family. Why are you staying at home?" And it can be really hard for them because maybe it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them, and maybe the wife has a better job, and it's working out fine for them. But society looks down on that. And in the fashion industry, often people don't take men seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that makes sense. But I think it's because men who are typically into fashion... I think they have different lifestyles. And if a man has the typical lifestyle and is in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women? Like, you don't really know what our case is like? Like these other guys." And so, depending on the field of work you're in, I think there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of difficult because society has a fixed mindset and, obviously, we've come a long way from the 1800s, but change is slow. So, I think that if we continue to work at the pace we are now because women are advancing to higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world, but it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And similarly, as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, maybe the woman has a better job or she wants to be the one who works." And then for people in fashion, it'll be like, "Oh, maybe they're listening to their female friends or their wives, and so they know where I'm coming from." So, I guess you have to kind of promote it by showing the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against, not being too pushy, but showing the qualities of them. Because if you force it, people will resist. And I think we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So, I don't really know if there's anything we can do now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast, people will resist, and we've come a long way, and change takes time. Yes. And I think they're also discriminated against each other, depending on the type of job you have or where you come from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't so good, but you're extremely intelligent and you work your way up to a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men will look down on you and be like, "How do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So, yeah, sometimes it's where you come from that discriminates against you, and from gender to gender. And I don't know, I think that would be another example. Not really.

transformed_texts: I think that the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. Their views on various issues seem outdated. Many people think the Catholic Church is losing influence because it's not very open to many things. They have strong views on topics like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which can be a turn-off for some people. If they were to adapt to a newer way of thinking, they might not lose their following. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because of how it views certain issues. The Catholic Church is against abortion, which can make it difficult for people who are pro-choice to be part of the community. The same goes for gay marriage and other similar issues. The Church's stance on these topics can be a major reason for people to leave. I don't see why priests can't be married or have female priests. The Church says that priests are "married" to God, but I don't think that's a valid reason for not allowing them to have a family life. Everyone else in the world has a job and a family life, so why can't priests?

Personally, I'm not opposed to same-sex marriage. I think it's not a decision that people make consciously. So I think that gay people shouldn't be held responsible for their sexual orientation.

I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't really put much thought into the topic, but I think it's wrong to say that it's not okay.

It doesn't seem like they have a choice in how they are. I mean, I was born straight, and another person might be born gay. It doesn't seem like they make a conscious decision that they should be held responsible for.

I think it's wrong for the federal government to get involved, as it's not a legal issue or a moral issue. I don't think these gay people should be put on a stage like they made a wrong decision or choice.

I don't think the federal government really has any say in this matter. It's hard [laughs].

I don't think the federal government should be involved because it has nothing to do with the security of our country, nor is it a moral concern. It just seems like they're out of place. It doesn't seem like they have any right to interfere in people's lives, and they're just who they are. Gay people are who they were born to be, and they shouldn't be punished for that.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there isn't a good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's just different and there are so many different aspects that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two different sides of the same coin, heads will never be tails but it's like the same thing. There are a lot of civil rights that go along with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing where your primary or your next of kin can't be in the room with you if you're sick and can't visit because they're not technically family. And I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. A lot of scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days and homosexual couples have the same kind of rates of success, they have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just, it's a relationship, it's the same thing. I think where a lot of people get hung up on is homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state then that shouldn't be an issue. If you're allowing someone a civil union, why not a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. I think that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. And it's not just for women. I think it has to do with the specific field of work that one is in. I mean, in general, I feel that women have it harder because there's the "glass ceiling" where, even though it's supposed to be about equality, most people have a hard time finding someone to work under a woman if they're a man because the society has been raised for so long. And often, women in the workplace see that there's a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't promote them to that position because, historically, it's been shown that women are not usually in the upper levels of the business world. And I think the same thing goes for men. And in other fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's really rare for a man to be at home. And often, people look down on that because society thinks, "Oh, you're a man, you should be working. You should be the breadwinner of your family. Why are you staying at home?" And it can be really hard for them because maybe it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them, and maybe the wife has a better job, and it's working out fine for them. But society looks down on that. And in the fashion industry, often people don't take men seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that makes sense. But I think it's because men who are typically into fashion... I think they have different lifestyles. And if a man has the typical lifestyle and is in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women? Like, you don't really know what our case is like? Like these other guys." And so, depending on the field of work you're in, I think there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of difficult because society has a fixed mindset and, obviously, we've come a long way from the 1800s, but change is slow. So, I think that if we continue to work at the pace we are now because women are advancing to higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world, but it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And similarly, as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, maybe the woman has a better job or she wants to be the one who works." And then for people in fashion, it'll be like, "Oh, maybe they're listening to their female friends or their wives, and so they know where I'm coming from." So, I guess you have to kind of promote it by showing the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against, not being too pushy, but showing the qualities of them. Because if you force it, people will resist. And I think we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So, I don't really know if there's anything we can do now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast, people will resist, and we've come a long way, and change takes time. Yes. And I think they're also discriminated against each other, depending on the type of job you have or where you come from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't so good, but you're extremely intelligent and you work your way up to a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men will look down on you and be like, "How do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So, yeah, sometimes it's where you come from that discriminates against you, and from gender to gender. And I don't know, I think that would be another example. Not really.

Okay, initially I was for it because I was personally affected by 9/11. 
Also, I was for going back and basically creating as much chaos as they did here. 
However, I think we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long-term consequences because it was such an emotional event. 
And we just went there without being prepared and without a plan. 
And I think that backfired on us. 
I don't know, I was for it, but now I'm very against it. 
I don't think it achieved anything. 
I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't be fighting with us as well. 
I don't think our presence there is going to make a difference if they can't even get along with themselves. 
It's unfortunate, but due to 9/11, I'm almost indifferent to what happens over there. 
I just don't care about those people. 
I just think they're not human sometimes. 
I don't know, they fight with each other and can't do anything themselves. 
So, I really don't care. 
I don't know, we definitely went there unprepared. 
We didn't know what to expect over there. 
It's also bad because war is viewed very differently over there than it is here. 
They're just savage people when it comes to war and I don't think they're interested in improving their country. 
I just think they want us out of there. 
And I think that would be okay for us. 
I think we should just leave and that's it. 
I think we were just hyped up when we went there. 
I don't think we thought rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle. 
I think we pretty much just went there seeking revenge and I think President Bush went there because the people wanted to go there because of 9/11. 
Also, I think he took it upon himself to declare war on Iraq. 
But at the time, I understand where he was coming from. 
We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, "Let's rebuild and that's it." 
So, I don't think we could have just left it. 
But I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do in terms of creating order. 
I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do. 
And I don't know, I just think they didn't have unity. 
They didn't know what they were going in there for. 
So, I think that would have helped us a lot more. 
But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with. 
So, that's what we created there. 
Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. 
Honestly, I think they're always going to be like that. 
And I don't, I really don't have anything else to say. 
It's gone on for long enough. 
I don't think we're making enough progress. 
We've made progress, but not enough to stay there. 
And I think no matter how long we stay there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. 
And we can't stay there forever. 
So, I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying there. 
No, okay.

Therefore, I think the Church has the wrong view on things. The same goes for gay marriage, where if you believe in it and want to do it or feel strongly about it, you might not want to be in a community that doesn't agree with it. I haven't really thought about the topic, but I'd definitely say it's wrong to say that. It seems it's not really a choice; they don't really have a choice in who they are. Like, I was born straight, and I guess another person is born gay. It doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice they should be held responsible for. I'd definitely think it's wrong to say they made a wrong decision. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not something affecting our country's security or moral issues. I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there's simply no good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's so different and there are so many different aspects to it that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two different sides of the same coin; heads will never be tails. But it's like the same thing, and there are a lot of civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing, where your primary or next of kin can't even be in the room with you if you're sick. It's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone and lots of scientific studies have been done, and homosexual couples have the same kind of success rates as heterosexual couples. They have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction. It's just a relationship, it's the same thing. I think where a lot of people get hung up is that homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. I don't understand where people, like Catholics, get hung up on saying it's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing. But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Yes, they are the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners and stuff like that. People worry about adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. And especially about children of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society, and whether or not they'll be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation, or not. But again, it's kind of new and stuff, but it's kind of hard to say I'm not sure about the children aspect about adoption, because I think the main drawback to that is how children get treated by their peers and by other adults in society. Like in New York City, I know they have special schools for children of gay parents, because in public schools in New York City they get beaten up and stuff like that. Parents protest to get the child removed from their school, and it's just a kid, I mean they're going to have the same points of view and everything, parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. And so they can be community involved or not like heterosexual couples choose to, it's just about personality choices. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But I think President Bush has very strong views of his own to do with his religion. Well, his take on gay marriage actually goes along with his take on abortion and stem cell research, which I think most of the reasons I've heard at least in the news and stuff are moral reasons, and morality I don't want to say it's negotiable, but it definitely differs from person to person. And to embrace the morality of a certain group in America while totally ignoring the culture and morality concepts of all the rest is unethical. To just go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account the culture and morality of all the rest is hypocritical of the government, considering the recent controversy, considering I mean about under God in the pledge of allegiance and how people are so opposed to that, but yet they'll let laws be made that enforce religious standards on an entire country. Just one, lots of people are anti-gay and anti-gay-marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged, and the gayness has resulted from trauma in their childhood not being close enough to one or the other of the parents, or just a personality defect. At the beginning I was okay with the idea, but I think everyone was still reeling from the 9/11 attacks and I think we went into Iraq as a pretext - there were pretexts that led us into Iraq. I think the Bush administration initially linked the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks and claimed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, all of which has since been proven false. And that really rubbed me the wrong way and in general the Iraq war still boils my blood. 

Um, It just seems to me that the Bush administration has been very openly lying to the American people and has yet to own up to that fact. Even Colin Powell, I mean, coming back from that big presentation he gave at the UN now says that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. And to me that's just malfeasance in office, I think that's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since 9/11, at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war. Just from the news reports I've heard it doesn't seem that the parliament is very effective at all, that um, Oh I don't remember his name but the Prime Minister really has no control over the political process or what's happening and even Muqtada al-Sadr the guy we were fighting I guess it was less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi parliament and I mean we're still dealing with fractious radical elements who are vying for control of the government, and I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that. I think if they adapted to a more modern way of thinking, they wouldn't have to worry about losing their followers. I've heard that many people are starting to turn away from the Catholic Church because of their views on these situations and because people disagree with them on certain subjects. Therefore, I think the Church has the wrong view on things. I mean, the Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion, you might not feel comfortable in a community where it's taught to be completely wrong and you're against it. The same goes for gay marriage, where if you believe in it and want to do it or feel strongly about it, you might not want to be in a community that doesn't agree with it. I don't see any reason why priests can't be married or have female priests, but I don't know if that would have prevented what happened. Maybe they wouldn't have done it if they were allowed to be married or have women priests, but I don't know if that would have necessarily changed things. I mean, that was something they did, and it didn't seem to be affected. If they were married, would they have done it differently? It's hard to tell. I don't see why priests can't be married. The Church says that priests are married to God, but everyone else in the world has a job and a family life. I don't see why priests can't have both. No.

Gay people shouldn't be held responsible for their sexual orientation. I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't really thought about the topic, but I'd definitely say it's wrong to say that. It seems it's not really a choice; they don't really have a choice in who they are. Like, I was born straight, and I guess another person is born gay. It doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice they should be held responsible for. I'd definitely think it's wrong to say they made a wrong decision. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not something affecting our country's security or moral issues. It just seems like they're out of place. They don't seem to have the right to intervene in people's lives. That's just who they are - gay people, that's how they were born, at least that's what I think. And they shouldn't be punished for that. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a security concern or a moral issue; it's just not their place. It's hard. I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there's simply no good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's so different and there are so many different aspects to it that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two different sides of the same coin; heads will never be tails. But it's like the same thing, and there are a lot of civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing, where your primary or next of kin can't even be in the room with you if you're sick. It's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone and lots of scientific studies have been done, and homosexual couples have the same kind of success rates as heterosexual couples. They have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction. It's just a relationship, it's the same thing. I think where a lot of people get hung up is that homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. I don't understand where people, like Catholics, get hung up on saying it's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing. But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Yes, they are the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners and stuff like that. People worry about adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. And especially about children of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society, and whether or not they'll be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation, or not. But again, it's kind of new and stuff, but it's kind of hard to say I'm not sure about the children aspect about adoption, because I think the main drawback to that is how children get treated by their peers and by other adults in society. Like in New York City, I know they have special schools for children of gay parents, because in public schools in New York City they get beaten up and stuff like that. Parents protest to get the child removed from their school, and it's just a kid, I mean they're going to have the same points of view and everything, parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. And so they can be community involved or not like heterosexual couples choose to, it's just about personality choices. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But I think President Bush has very strong views of his own to do with his religion. Well, his take on gay marriage actually goes along with his take on abortion and stem cell research, which I think most of the reasons I've heard at least in the news and stuff are moral reasons, and morality I don't want to say it's negotiable, but it definitely differs from person to person. And to embrace the morality of a certain group in America while totally ignoring the culture and morality concepts of all the rest is unethical. To just go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account the culture and morality of all the rest is hypocritical of the government, considering the recent controversy, considering I mean about under God in the pledge of allegiance and how people are so opposed to that, but yet they'll let laws be made that enforce religious standards on an entire country. Just one, lots of people are anti-gay and anti-gay-marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged, and the gayness has resulted from trauma in their childhood not being close enough to one or the other of the parents, or just a personality defect. At the beginning I was okay with the idea, but I think everyone was still reeling from the 9/11 attacks and I think we went into Iraq as a pretext - there were pretexts that led us into Iraq. I think the Bush administration initially linked the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks and claimed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, all of which has since been proven false. And that really rubbed me the wrong way and in general the Iraq war still boils my blood. 

Um, It just seems to me that the Bush administration has been very openly lying to the American people and has yet to own up to that fact. Even Colin Powell, I mean, coming back from that big presentation he gave at the UN now says that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. And to me that's just malfeasance in office, I think that's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since 9/11, at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war. Um, That last part I forget the name of the Secretary of the treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was probably forced out of his office. Um, But it seems to me that the younger Bush had a kind of bloodlust against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration and I think that in the long term he was hoping to expand our energy supply too, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. Well, I do think it's gone on long enough, I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now because there's a good chance that the country would lapse into civil war and even more people would die as a result. Um, I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving to at this point seems to be kind of like a coalition of nations from the surrounding area like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and try to restore order, but I don't necessarily know that's a good idea because I think in the long term that will also cause more problems because Iraq's sovereignty will become an issue, a major issue there because I think it's pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point. Just from the news reports I've heard it doesn't seem that the parliament is very effective at all, that um, Oh I don't remember his name but the Prime Minister really has no control over the political process or what's happening and even Muqtada al-Sadr the guy we were fighting I guess it was less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi parliament and I mean we're still dealing with fractious radical elements who are vying for control of the government, and I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that. I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there's simply no good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's so different and there are so many different aspects to it that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two different sides of the same coin; heads will never be tails. But it's like the same thing, and there are a lot of civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing, where your primary or next of kin can't even be in the room with you if you're sick. It's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone and lots of scientific studies have been done, and homosexual couples have the same kind of success rates as heterosexual couples. They have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction. It's just a relationship, it's the same thing. I think where a lot of people get hung up is that homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. I don't understand where people, like Catholics, get hung up on saying it's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing. But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Yes, they are the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners and stuff like that. People worry about adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. And especially about children of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society, and whether or not they'll be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation, or not. Like in New York City, I know they have special schools for children of gay parents, because in public schools in New York City they get beaten up and stuff like that. Parents protest to get the child removed from their school, and it's just a kid, I mean they're going to have the same points of view and everything, parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. And so they can be community involved or not like heterosexual couples choose to, it's just about personality choices. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But I think President Bush has very strong views of his own to do with his religion. And to embrace the morality of a certain group in America while totally ignoring the culture and morality concepts of all the rest is unethical. To just go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account the culture and morality of all the rest is hypocritical of the government, considering the recent controversy, considering I mean about under God in the pledge of allegiance and how people are so opposed to that, but yet they'll let laws be made that enforce religious standards on an entire country. I think the Bush administration initially linked the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks and claimed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, all of which has since been proven false. Um, It just seems to me that the Bush administration has been very openly lying to the American people and has yet to own up to that fact. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since 9/11, at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war. And I would see all my friends there on Sundays. And we would just go there. But now that I've grown older, they've introduced a "teenager mass." And they've cut it down to thirty minutes. And people wear a lot more casual clothing. Especially in the summer, people come in their beach clothes, straight from the beach. You'd have the families there who are just running in late. So I think it's become much more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to always get dressed up, people wear jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too. But it's just much more casual compared to that. As for other things, that's the biggest thing I've noticed. Like, that's the church I know; I don't know the church politics and whatnot. And people wear a lot more casual clothing. Especially in the summer, people come in their beach clothes, straight from the beach. You'd have the families there who are just running in late. So I think it's become much more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to always get dressed up, people wear jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too. And people wear a lot more casual clothing. Especially in the summer, people come in their beach clothes, straight from the beach. You'd have the families there who are just running in late. So I think it's become much more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to always get dressed up, people wear jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too. I think the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. Their views are a bit old-fashioned. They have strong opinions on many things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. I think this is one of the reasons why the Catholic Church is losing followers. They are not very open to many things. 

I think if they were to adapt a bit, they wouldn't lose as many followers. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because they don't share their views. They think the Catholic Church has the wrong views. If you're for abortion, for example, you might not feel comfortable in a community that believes abortion is wrong. The same goes for gay marriage and other things. If you believe the Catholic Church is wrong, you might not be able to join a community that upholds these views. I think there's no reason why priests can't get married or why there can't be female priests. But I'm not sure if that would have made a difference. 

If priests got married or there were female priests, it might not have made a difference. It's hard to say if they would have acted differently. I think there's no reason why priests can't get married. The Catholic Church says priests are married to God, but I don't think that's the same as a marriage. Everyone has a job and a family and other people they love. Why shouldn't that be the same for priests?

I personally don't oppose men getting married. I think one doesn't consciously decide whether to be gay or not. I think you shouldn't be held responsible for who you are. I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but people of the same sex can't. I haven't given this much thought, but I think it's wrong for them to say that. 

It seems to me that it's not like a choice whether you're gay or not. I mean, you're either gay or straight, and that's something you can't actively choose. It's like being born gay or not, and I think it's wrong to hold someone responsible for their sexual orientation. 

I think the federal government shouldn't interfere because it's not a legal or moral issue. I mean, you should just accept who you are and not try to change someone. It's tough to exclude the federal government, but I think they shouldn't interfere because it's not their business. 

It's hard to exclude them, but I think they shouldn't interfere because it's not their thing. It's not about national security or moral concerns, it's just that they're out of place. It doesn't seem like they have the right to interfere in people's lives. And you know, that's who they are, the gay people, that's just how they were born, at least that's what I think, and I mean they shouldn't be punished for that.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there isn’t a good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but they are just different. It’s like two different sides of the same coin, and heads will never be tails, but it’s the same thing. There are many civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and healthcare, where your primary or next of kin can’t visit because they aren’t technically family. It’s silly to spend the rest of your life with someone but not be able to have them in the room with you if you’re sick. Many scientific studies have been done and they show that homosexual couples have the same success rates and the same factors that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It’s just a relationship, it’s the same thing. Where people get hung up is that homosexuals aren’t asking for the right to get married in a church, they’re asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no involvement with church and state, then it shouldn’t be an issue. The Catholic church can believe whatever they want, but it shouldn’t be an issue in a legal sense. If you’re allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It’s like segregation, separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the roles played by different partners and so on. People are worried about adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. They are especially worried about children of gay couples and how they’ll adjust to society, but it’s hard to say. The main drawback to adoption is how children get treated by their peers and by other adults in society. In New York City, they have special schools for children of gay parents because in public schools, kids get bullied and beat up, and parents protest to get them removed from school. It’s just a kid, they have the same points of view and everything, and parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. They can be community involved or not like heterosexual couples choose to. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But President Bush has very strong views related to his religion. His views on gay marriage go along with his views on abortion and stem cell research, and most of the reasons I’ve heard are moral reasons. Morality is not always negotiable, but it differs from person to person. It’s not fair to embrace the morality of one group in America while ignoring the culture and morality of the rest. It’s not fair to go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account the whole country. It’s hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage considering the recent controversy over “under God” in the pledge of allegiance, and how people are opposed to that but will let laws be made that enforce religious standards on the whole country. Many people are against gay people and gay marriage because they believe they are somehow psychologically damaged. The American Psychological Association has just put out a memo saying that is untrue. If people listened to institutions that actually do research and studies on these subjects instead of their neighbors and friends, and maybe what’s popular opinion in their culture and church, then the world would be seen a little bit differently. No.

I was initially okay with the premise, but I think that everyone was still pretty much reeling from the 9/11 attacks and I think that we kind of went into Iraq as a pretext there were pretexts that led us into Iraq. I think that the Bush administration was quick to connect the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction all of which has since been proven false. And that really rubbed me the wrong way and in general the Iraq war really boils my blood. I was initially for the Iraq war, but now I think it was a bad idea to think that we would find WMDs in Iraq. I think that the Bush administration very openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, I mean, after he came back from that big presentation he gave at the UN, says that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. And that is a perversion of the constitution, I think that is an impeachable offense because they lied to the American people. I think that the Bush administration completely disregards the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since September 11. Honestly, I think they had the intention to go to war from the start. I think they went into Iraq to secure their energy supply, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. I think it's gone on long enough, but I also think that if we withdraw now, there's a good chance that the country will plunge into civil war and even more people will die as a result. I think that the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving towards now seems to be a coalition of nations from the surrounding area like Syria and Saudi Arabia coming in to try to restore order. But I'm not sure that's a good idea because I think it will also cause more problems in the long term because Iraq's sovereignty will become a major point of contention. I think the interim government is dissolving because it's not effective. I've heard that the parliament is not very effective and that the Prime Minister doesn't have control over the political process or what's happening. And also Mugtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting, I think it was less than a year ago, his party now has at least 20 seats in the Iraqi parliament and I think we're still dealing with radical elements that are vying for control of the government. I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that. I can't discuss this in polite company.

I think the war has been going on for too long, I think the purpose in the beginning was good. To restore democracy in another country is a good purpose. But I think we've long since lost sight of that purpose and we're now maybe just doing it because we're doing it to prove that we're some sort of superpower in the world. I also think the original motivations were questionable because of George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 

So, I think if the original motivation was to give democracy to a country that didn't have a fair political system, then that would be a fair motivation, if there were personal matters involved I don't think it would have been fair. But I do think it's been drawn out. I think we got our purpose across in the first couple of months just starting the war, I think that was a statement in and of itself. But the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too long.

Yeah, I think. I mean, if our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose and that's a good reason for the war. But I don't think our reason over time has been deteriorated and misconceived. It seems like we're still at war just to go to war, and we don't want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or whatever.

Yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean, there comes a point when their government, their officials are gonna have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. We've long since been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars when we have our own wars on our own turf, like poverty and so on, that we should be spending that money on. I think it's a drain on our economy for a purpose that's long since been drawn out.

Yeah, I mean, they're spending billions and billions of dollars, and war shouldn't be in our budget for the long term. There are obvious things like poverty or internal improvements, you know, public roads or anything dealing with schools. We certainly have a lot of problems funding things like that, healthcare, that I think that money could be much better spent on. Right now that money's being spent to have some of our own citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we've lost the cause for.

Look, we're just going to talk about the Iraq War one more time. I mean, I feel hypocritical talking about it. I mean, I hate to say you know, I hate joining the bandwagon of people who say I was against it from the beginning. Yeah, I was, but it's not really important anymore because the general consensus everywhere was that it was a bad idea, except within the administration because they don't want to admit they were wrong. And I mean, you just have to look at the recent polls. They've done US polls, Iraqi polls, global polls, and I mean, no, about seventy-five to eighty percent of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of the troops that are over there, like the US troops that are over there right now, think it was a dumb idea and that we should pull out within the year. I don't know, it's just been a complete disaster from before we even went in. It was already a disaster, and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There's really no easy way to deal with the Middle East anymore. I mean, I think it's just the cultural clash between the United States and the Middle Eastern states, I mean, it's just too big a gap for this administration or previous administrations to understand. And they think they can just bring democracy into an area where it shouldn't exist, like that's not the way that totally different people would choose to run their lives. I mean, sure, Saddam was a bad guy, I don't think anyone's arguing that he wasn't, but, I mean, you have to weigh the pros and cons before you invade a country that's going to turn into just a complete disaster, like quicksand when we went over there. I don't even know what to say about it. I don't really see a reason at all to stay in there. I mean, I'm sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas as to why it's better to stay in there, and you know the problems that might arise from us pulling out, I don't agree with them, I've yet to hear a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. I mean, if they want to do it gradually over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, I guess I wouldn't really have a problem with that, but, I just don't see a reason why we shouldn't just leave now. I mean, I read this statistic a little while ago, that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year and at least a quarter of them think that we should just leave now. And like these people that we're trying to save, these people that we're trying to help, are telling us to leave. Yeah, I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them if we should leave and they say yes, then you know it's not on us if something happens. If it completely goes to hell, we could be like well we were going to stay in but you guys made the decision not to. And then you know at least we'll, I mean if we decide to help out after that, we'll at least be the good guys, kind of, not really, no, we'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it'll be better than where we stand right now.

I think that gender discrimination is still an issue in the US. 

Not just for women, I think it has to do with the specific field of work you're in. 

I mean, overall, I think women have it harder because of the "glass ceiling" where even with equal opportunities, most people have a hard time finding someone who works under a woman if they're a man. 

Because society has been built this way for so long. 

And often in the workplace, women see that there's a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't promote them to that position just because historically, it's not seen that women are usually in the upper echelons of the business world. 

And, I think the same goes for men. 

In certain industries like fashion or raising children at home, it's really uncommon for a man to stay at home and take care of the children. 

And often, people will look down on them because society thinks, "Well, you're a man, you should be working and making money, why are you staying at home?" 

And it can be really hard for them because maybe it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them, and the woman has a better job. 

And it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on it. 

In the fashion industry, it's often the case that people won't take straight men seriously who are interested in fashion. 

I don't know if that makes sense, but I think it's because men who are interested in fashion often have a different lifestyle. 

So if you have a typical lifestyle and you're a man and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women, like you don't really know what our case is like, like the other guys." 

And depending on the field of work you're in, I think there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the US. 

It's hard to change because society has a set mindset, and we've made huge progress since the 1800s, but it's a slow process. 

If we continue at the same rate because women are rising to higher positions and becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in the business world, it's a long process. 

But it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. 

And just like men who stay at home to raise their children, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh wait, maybe the woman has the better job or she wants to be the one working." 

And in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Oh wait, maybe they're listening to their female friends or wives and stuff, so they do know where I'm coming from." 

So maybe you have to promote it by showing the good qualities of people who are stereotyped against without being too pushy. 

If you force it, people will resist. 

And I think we're in a good balance where it's starting to permeate that way. 

So I don't really know if there's anything we can do now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, people will resist. 

And we've made progress, and change takes time. 

Yes, and... 

There is also discrimination between genders, depending on the field of work you're in or where you're from. 

If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't that great, but you're extremely intelligent and you worked your way up to a CEO position, other men will look down on you because they'll say, "I don't know if you really know what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right." 

So it's sometimes like where you're from discriminates against you. 

And between genders. 

I don't know, I think that would be another example.

Okay, let's talk about war. At first, I was all for it because I was personally affected by 9/11. I was for going over there and causing as much chaos as they caused here. I think that since it was such an emotional thing that happened, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long-term consequences. We went there without a plan and were unprepared. I think that ultimately backfired on us. I don't know, I was for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think we accomplished anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't fight with us as well. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. Unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost lost all feelings for what's going on over there. I just don't care about them. I don't think they're human, I don't know. They're just fighting with each other and can't get anything done, so I really don't care. We went over there completely unprepared, we didn't know what we were going to face over there. It's also bad because war is different for them than it is for us. They're like savage people when it comes to war and I don't think they're looking to better their country, I think they're just looking to get us out of there. And I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We were just hyped up, I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle. We pretty much just went over there looking for revenge, I think, and I think President Bush just went over there because pretty much the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. But also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. At the time, I see where he was coming from, we really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, 'Okay, let's rebuild and that's it.' So, I don't think we could have let it go, but I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of creating order. I don't know, I just think that they didn't have any unity, they didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn in there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people, I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And I don't, I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. We've made progress, but not enough to stay in there. And I think no matter how long we stay in there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. And we can't stay over there forever, so I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying over there. No, okay.

I think the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. Their views are a bit old-fashioned. They have strong opinions on many things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. I think this is one of the reasons why the Catholic Church is losing followers. They are not very open to many things. 

I think if they were to adapt a bit, they wouldn't lose as many followers. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because they don't share their views. They think the Catholic Church has the wrong views. If you're for abortion, for example, you might not feel comfortable in a community that believes abortion is wrong. The same goes for gay marriage and other things. If you believe the Catholic Church is wrong, you might not be able to join a community that upholds these views. I think there's no reason why priests can't get married or why there can't be female priests. But I'm not sure if that would have made a difference. 

If priests got married or there were female priests, it might not have made a difference. It's hard to say if they would have acted differently. I think there's no reason why priests can't get married. The Catholic Church says priests are married to God, but I don't think that's the same as a marriage. Everyone has a job and a family and other people they love. Why shouldn't that be the same for priests?

I personally don't oppose men getting married. I think one doesn't consciously decide whether to be gay or not. I think you shouldn't be held responsible for who you are. I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but people of the same sex can't. I haven't given this much thought, but I think it's wrong for them to say that. 

It seems to me that it's not like a choice whether you're gay or not. I mean, you're either gay or straight, and that's something you can't actively choose. It's like being born gay or not, and I think it's wrong to hold someone responsible for their sexual orientation. 

I think the federal government shouldn't interfere because it's not a legal or moral issue. I mean, you should just accept who you are and not try to change someone. It's tough to exclude the federal government, but I think they shouldn't interfere because it's not their business. 

It's hard to exclude them, but I think they shouldn't interfere because it's not their thing. It's not about national security or moral concerns, it's just that they're out of place. It doesn't seem like they have the right to interfere in people's lives. And you know, that's who they are, the gay people, that's just how they were born, at least that's what I think, and I mean they shouldn't be punished for that.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there isn’t a good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but they are just different. It’s like two different sides of the same coin, and heads will never be tails, but it’s the same thing. There are many civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and healthcare, where your primary or next of kin can’t visit because they aren’t technically family. It’s silly to spend the rest of your life with someone but not be able to have them in the room with you if you’re sick. Many scientific studies have been done and they show that homosexual couples have the same success rates and the same factors that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It’s just a relationship, it’s the same thing. Where people get hung up is that homosexuals aren’t asking for the right to get married in a church, they’re asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no involvement with church and state, then it shouldn’t be an issue. The Catholic church can believe whatever they want, but it shouldn’t be an issue in a legal sense. If you’re allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It’s like segregation, separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the roles played by different partners and so on. People are worried about adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. They are especially worried about children of gay couples and how they’ll adjust to society, but it’s hard to say. The main drawback to adoption is how children get treated by their peers and by other adults in society. In New York City, they have special schools for children of gay parents because in public schools, kids get bullied and beat up, and parents protest to get them removed from school. It’s just a kid, they have the same points of view and everything, and parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. They can be community involved or not like heterosexual couples choose to. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But President Bush has very strong views related to his religion. His views on gay marriage go along with his views on abortion and stem cell research, and most of the reasons I’ve heard are moral reasons. Morality is not always negotiable, but it differs from person to person. It’s not fair to embrace the morality of one group in America while ignoring the culture and morality of the rest. It’s not fair to go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account the whole country. It’s hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage considering the recent controversy over “under God” in the pledge of allegiance, and how people are opposed to that but will let laws be made that enforce religious standards on the whole country. Many people are against gay people and gay marriage because they believe they are somehow psychologically damaged. The American Psychological Association has just put out a memo saying that is untrue. If people listened to institutions that actually do research and studies on these subjects instead of their neighbors and friends, and maybe what’s popular opinion in their culture and church, then the world would be seen a little bit differently. No.

I think the church has already changed to adapt to the 21st century. I understand that it's not as strict as it used to be. I know, even as I've grown up, when I was younger I would always go to church every Sunday. And I would wear cute little dresses. And I would wear matching shoes. And I would wear a matching purse. That was the case when I went to a private school. And I would see all my friends on the weekends. And we would just go. But now, as I've gotten older, they've made like a teenager mass. And they cut it down to 30 minutes. And people dress a lot more casually. Especially in the summer, people would come in their beach clothes, straight from the beach. You'd have families there who are just running late. So I think it's become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to always dress up. People are wearing jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too. But it's just a lot more casual compared to that. What I've noticed is that that's the biggest thing that's changed. That's the church I know. I don't know the politics of the church and whatnot. But yeah, that's it. [OK, what exactly do you have to say about the accusations against Catholic priests regarding pedophilia?] I don't think these things could have been prevented. Because there are men who are married, and they still become pedophiles, and they still have an attraction towards young kids. I think even if you let them get married, it's just the person. It's not because they're allowed to get married or not. I also think that when they become a priest, it's their decision. There are religions where they're allowed to get married. For example, on Seventh Heaven. I don't know what kind of [a reverend or a minister or something]. [mm hmm] But they're allowed to get married. I know it's a little different. If they really want to practice their faith and get married at the same time, they should maybe choose a different faith. [OK, can you elaborate on your answer a little bit more?] Um, about the changes. [That it really wouldn't make a difference, I guess.] Oh, pedophilia. [Mm hmm] I think like the whole thing, sexual attraction before, as if it were genetics. I think it's based on genetics. I don't think people become it. I think they're born that way. I don't think it has anything to do with upbringing. It might have something to do a little bit in this case, but I think it's their genetics. And you can't hide that through a marriage. You could try, but then it would usually come out. So I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening. If they knew about it and were trying to cover it up, then shame on them, but I don't think in all cases they knew. [OK, do you have any other thoughts concerning the Catholic Church?] No

I was initially okay with the premise, but I think that everyone was still pretty much reeling from the 9/11 attacks and I think that we kind of went into Iraq as a pretext there were pretexts that led us into Iraq. I think that the Bush administration was quick to connect the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction all of which has since been proven false. And that really rubbed me the wrong way and in general the Iraq war really boils my blood. I was initially for the Iraq war, but now I think it was a bad idea to think that we would find WMDs in Iraq. I think that the Bush administration very openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, I mean, after he came back from that big presentation he gave at the UN, says that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. And that is a perversion of the constitution, I think that is an impeachable offense because they lied to the American people. I think that the Bush administration completely disregards the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since September 11. Honestly, I think they had the intention to go to war from the start. I think they went into Iraq to secure their energy supply, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. I think it's gone on long enough, but I also think that if we withdraw now, there's a good chance that the country will plunge into civil war and even more people will die as a result. I think that the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving towards now seems to be a coalition of nations from the surrounding area like Syria and Saudi Arabia coming in to try to restore order. But I'm not sure that's a good idea because I think it will also cause more problems in the long term because Iraq's sovereignty will become a major point of contention. I think the interim government is dissolving because it's not effective. I've heard that the parliament is not very effective and that the Prime Minister doesn't have control over the political process or what's happening. And also Mugtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting, I think it was less than a year ago, his party now has at least 20 seats in the Iraqi parliament and I think we're still dealing with radical elements that are vying for control of the government. I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that. I can't discuss this in polite company.

I think the war has been going on for too long, I think the purpose in the beginning was good. To restore democracy in another country is a good purpose. But I think we've long since lost sight of that purpose and we're now maybe just doing it because we're doing it to prove that we're some sort of superpower in the world. I also think the original motivations were questionable because of George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 

So, I think if the original motivation was to give democracy to a country that didn't have a fair political system, then that would be a fair motivation, if there were personal matters involved I don't think it would have been fair. But I do think it's been drawn out. I think we got our purpose across in the first couple of months just starting the war, I think that was a statement in and of itself. But the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too long.

Yeah, I think. I mean, if our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose and that's a good reason for the war. But I don't think our reason over time has been deteriorated and misconceived. It seems like we're still at war just to go to war, and we don't want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or whatever.

Yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean, there comes a point when their government, their officials are gonna have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. Look, we're just going to talk about the Iraq War one more time. I mean, I feel hypocritical talking about it. I mean, I hate to say you know, I hate joining the bandwagon of people who say I was against it from the beginning. Yeah, I was, but it's not really important anymore because the general consensus everywhere was that it was a bad idea, except within the administration because they don't want to admit they were wrong. And I mean, you just have to look at the recent polls. They've done US polls, Iraqi polls, global polls, and I mean, no, about seventy-five to eighty percent of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of the troops that are over there, like the US troops that are over there right now, think it was a dumb idea and that we should pull out within the year. I don't know, it's just been a complete disaster from before we even went in. It was already a disaster, and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There's really no easy way to deal with the Middle East anymore. I mean, I think it's just the cultural clash between the United States and the Middle Eastern states, I mean, it's just too big a gap for this administration or previous administrations to understand. And they think they can just bring democracy into an area where it shouldn't exist, like that's not the way that totally different people would choose to run their lives. I mean, sure, Saddam was a bad guy, I don't think anyone's arguing that he wasn't, but, I mean, you have to weigh the pros and cons before you invade a country that's going to turn into just a complete disaster, like quicksand when we went over there. I don't even know what to say about it. I don't really see a reason at all to stay in there. I mean, I'm sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas as to why it's better to stay in there, and you know the problems that might arise from us pulling out, I don't agree with them, I've yet to hear a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. I mean, if they want to do it gradually over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, I guess I wouldn't really have a problem with that, but, I just don't see a reason why we shouldn't just leave now. I mean, I read this statistic a little while ago, that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year and at least a quarter of them think that we should just leave now. And like these people that we're trying to save, these people that we're trying to help, are telling us to leave. Yeah, I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them if we should leave and they say yes, then you know it's not on us if something happens. If it completely goes to hell, we could be like well we were going to stay in but you guys made the decision not to. And then you know at least we'll, I mean if we decide to help out after that, we'll at least be the good guys, kind of, not really, no, we'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it'll be better than where we stand right now.

I think that gender discrimination is still an issue in the US. 

Not just for women, I think it has to do with the specific field of work you're in. 

I mean, overall, I think women have it harder because of the "glass ceiling" where even with equal opportunities, most people have a hard time finding someone who works under a woman if they're a man. 

Because society has been built this way for so long. 

And often in the workplace, women see that there's a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't promote them to that position just because historically, it's not seen that women are usually in the upper echelons of the business world. 

And, I think the same goes for men. 

In certain industries like fashion or raising children at home, it's really uncommon for a man to stay at home and take care of the children. 

And often, people will look down on them because society thinks, "Well, you're a man, you should be working and making money, why are you staying at home?" 

And it can be really hard for them because maybe it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them, and the woman has a better job. 

And it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on it. 

In the fashion industry, it's often the case that people won't take straight men seriously who are interested in fashion. 

I don't know if that makes sense, but I think it's because men who are interested in fashion often have a different lifestyle. 

So if you have a typical lifestyle and you're a man and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women, like you don't really know what our case is like, like the other guys." 

And depending on the field of work you're in, I think there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the US. 

It's hard to change because society has a set mindset, and we've made huge progress since the 1800s, but it's a slow process. 

If we continue at the same rate because women are rising to higher positions and becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in the business world, it's a long process. 

But it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. 

And just like men who stay at home to raise their children, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh wait, maybe the woman has the better job or she wants to be the one working." 

And in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Oh wait, maybe they're listening to their female friends or wives and stuff, so they do know where I'm coming from." 

So maybe you have to promote it by showing the good qualities of people who are stereotyped against without being too pushy. 

If you force it, people will resist. 

And I think we're in a good balance where it's starting to permeate that way. 

So I don't really know if there's anything we can do now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, people will resist. 

And we've made progress, and change takes time. 

Yes, and... 

There is also discrimination between genders, depending on the field of work you're in or where you're from. 

If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't that great, but you're extremely intelligent and you worked your way up to a CEO position, other men will look down on you because they'll say, "I don't know if you really know what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right." 

So it's sometimes like where you're from discriminates against you. 

And between genders. 

I don't know, I think that would be another example.
