Okay, let's talk about war. At first, I was all for it because I was personally affected by 9/11. I was for going over there and causing as much chaos as they caused here. I think that since it was such an emotional thing that happened, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long-term consequences. We went there without a plan and were unprepared. I think that ultimately backfired on us. I don't know, I was for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think we accomplished anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't fight with us as well. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. Unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost lost all feelings for what's going on over there. I just don't care about them. I don't think they're human, I don't know. They're just fighting with each other and can't get anything done, so I really don't care. We went over there completely unprepared, we didn't know what we were going to face over there. It's also bad because war is different for them than it is for us. They're like savage people when it comes to war and I don't think they're looking to better their country, I think they're just looking to get us out of there. And I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We were just hyped up, I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle. We pretty much just went over there looking for revenge, I think, and I think President Bush just went over there because pretty much the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. But also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. At the time, I see where he was coming from, we really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, 'Okay, let's rebuild and that's it.' So, I don't think we could have let it go, but I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of creating order. I don't know, I just think that they didn't have any unity, they didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn in there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people, I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And I don't, I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. We've made progress, but not enough to stay in there. And I think no matter how long we stay in there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. And we can't stay over there forever, so I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying over there. No, okay.

I think the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. Their views are a bit old-fashioned. They have strong opinions on many things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. I think this is one of the reasons why the Catholic Church is losing followers. They are not very open to many things. 

I think if they were to adapt a bit, they wouldn't lose as many followers. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because they don't share their views. They think the Catholic Church has the wrong views. If you're for abortion, for example, you might not feel comfortable in a community that believes abortion is wrong. The same goes for gay marriage and other things. If you believe the Catholic Church is wrong, you might not be able to join a community that upholds these views. I think there's no reason why priests can't get married or why there can't be female priests. But I'm not sure if that would have made a difference. 

If priests got married or there were female priests, it might not have made a difference. It's hard to say if they would have acted differently. I think there's no reason why priests can't get married. The Catholic Church says priests are married to God, but I don't think that's the same as a marriage. Everyone has a job and a family and other people they love. Why shouldn't that be the same for priests?

I personally don't oppose men getting married. I think one doesn't consciously decide whether to be gay or not. I think you shouldn't be held responsible for who you are. I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but people of the same sex can't. I haven't given this much thought, but I think it's wrong for them to say that. 

It seems to me that it's not like a choice whether you're gay or not. I mean, you're either gay or straight, and that's something you can't actively choose. It's like being born gay or not, and I think it's wrong to hold someone responsible for their sexual orientation. 

I think the federal government shouldn't interfere because it's not a legal or moral issue. I mean, you should just accept who you are and not try to change someone. It's tough to exclude the federal government, but I think they shouldn't interfere because it's not their business. 

It's hard to exclude them, but I think they shouldn't interfere because it's not their thing. It's not about national security or moral concerns, it's just that they're out of place. It doesn't seem like they have the right to interfere in people's lives. And you know, that's who they are, the gay people, that's just how they were born, at least that's what I think, and I mean they shouldn't be punished for that.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there isn’t a good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but they are just different. It’s like two different sides of the same coin, and heads will never be tails, but it’s the same thing. There are many civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and healthcare, where your primary or next of kin can’t visit because they aren’t technically family. It’s silly to spend the rest of your life with someone but not be able to have them in the room with you if you’re sick. Many scientific studies have been done and they show that homosexual couples have the same success rates and the same factors that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It’s just a relationship, it’s the same thing. Where people get hung up is that homosexuals aren’t asking for the right to get married in a church, they’re asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no involvement with church and state, then it shouldn’t be an issue. The Catholic church can believe whatever they want, but it shouldn’t be an issue in a legal sense. If you’re allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It’s like segregation, separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the roles played by different partners and so on. People are worried about adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. They are especially worried about children of gay couples and how they’ll adjust to society, but it’s hard to say. The main drawback to adoption is how children get treated by their peers and by other adults in society. And often in the workplace, women see that there's a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't promote them to that position just because historically, it's not seen that women are usually in the upper echelons of the business world. 

And, I think the same goes for men. 

In certain industries like fashion or raising children at home, it's really uncommon for a man to stay at home and take care of the children. 

And often, people will look down on them because society thinks, "Well, you're a man, you should be working and making money, why are you staying at home?" 

And it can be really hard for them because maybe it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them, and the woman has a better job. 

And it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on it. 

In the fashion industry, it's often the case that people won't take straight men seriously who are interested in fashion. 

I don't know if that makes sense, but I think it's because men who are interested in fashion often have a different lifestyle. 

So if you have a typical lifestyle and you're a man and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women, like you don't really know what our case is like, like the other guys." 

And depending on the field of work you're in, I think there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the US. 

It's hard to change because society has a set mindset, and we've made huge progress since the 1800s, but it's a slow process. 

If we continue at the same rate because women are rising to higher positions and becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in the business world, it's a long process. 

But it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. 

And just like men who stay at home to raise their children, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh wait, maybe the woman has the better job or she wants to be the one working." 

And in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Oh wait, maybe they're listening to their female friends or wives and stuff, so they do know where I'm coming from." 

So maybe you have to promote it by showing the good qualities of people who are stereotyped against without being too pushy. 

If you force it, people will resist. 

And I think we're in a good balance where it's starting to permeate that way. 

So I don't really know if there's anything we can do now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, people will resist. 

And we've made progress, and change takes time. 

Yes, and... 

There is also discrimination between genders, depending on the field of work you're in or where you're from. 

If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't that great, but you're extremely intelligent and you worked your way up to a CEO position, other men will look down on you because they'll say, "I don't know if you really know what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right." 

So it's sometimes like where you're from discriminates against you. 

And between genders. 

I don't know, I think that would be another example.
